text:
One of the best things about TLotR is that, for every single member of the Fellowship (and for several others outside the Fellowship), the answer to the question "Did X save Middle-Earth?" the answer is "yes". EVERYONE had their role to play and it is made quite clear throughout the story that there was VERY little wiggle room for things to have gone differently. Had any of the Fellowship not been present or not been who they were or done things differently, there's a very real chance the Quest would have failed. But, at the same time, NONE of them did so on their own. NOBODY in the Fellowship can claim full credit for their victory. They all played their roles together even when they were, physically, apart and did not know they were working together.

To provide at least one example for each:
Frodo, obviously, is the Ring-Bearer
Sam gets Frodo to the Crack of Doom
Merry is instrumental in slaying the Witch King
Pippin...is this video. Just watch it.
Gimli rallies the people at Helm's Deep by blowing the horn
Legolas shoots down what was PROBABLY a Nazgul shortly before the breaking of the Fellowship (which likely saved them from being spotted) and may have been the reason the Elves of Lothlorien didn't kill them on sight.
Legolas and Gimli help Aragorn through his entire arc after the breaking of the Fellowship (though, it must be said, they are probably the LEAST influential members of the Fellowship)
Aragorn was, of course, the heir of Isildor and led the party after Gandalf's death
Gandalf was the party leader and the wisest among them
Boromir was the catalyst for Frodo leaving on his own, directed Aragorn, Legolas, and Gimli to chase Merry and Pippin, and was probably a major reason for why Aragorn decided to go to Gondor's aid rather than chase Frodo and Sam.

That is why Pippin as his son and heir gets to lead a company of Tooks to the battle of Bywater while Paladin leads the rest of his forces driving out Sharkey's men from the southern parts of the Shire.

So, his position is actually the exact same as Boromir's (son and heir of the king's representative in their respective country), which makes their story arc from Boromir's sacrifice to Pippin's pledge to Denethor even more poetic imo.

text:
Gandalf falling while defeating the Balrog alone is such an enormous example of the Butterfly Effect:
1. No more Balrog in the mix. Not only was it a very powerful evil thing in its own right, but it would've known Sauron & could easily be assumed to ally with him.
2. Gandalf gets promoted to Gandalf the White. Not only does this replace Saruman & give Gandalf the ability to break his staff & whatnot, but it gives Gandalf the extra powers we see him use openly later. Particularly, during the siege of Minas Tirith.
3. Without Gandalf the White, Rohan would absolutely have fallen. Gandalf & Shadowfax did SO MUCH to save & organize Rohan. Plus, Gandalf saved Th√©oden, which he wouldn't have been able to do as the Grey. 
4. Without both Rohan & Aragorn surviving the battle of Helm's Deep, then Minas Tirith absolutely would have fallen. Also, Gandalf's aforementioned use of power, when he openly defies the Nazg√ªl during the siege.
5. Without both kingdoms prevailing, the hundreds of thousands of Orcs would've been in the way of Frodo & Sam.
6. Faramir is the one who makes the speech that actually convinces everyone to agree that Aragorn deserves the kingship. So, Pippin's distracting Gandalf with saving Faramir essentially allowed for Aragorn to ascend the throne. Also, though it meant the death of Th√©oden, allowing the Witch-king to leave & going to save Faramir actually led to the fall of the Witch-king, despite how Gandalf felt in his choice not to pursue him.

text:
There's another aspect to Pippin dropping that stone down the well in Moria - had he not alerted the orcs and the Balrog to the Fellowship's presence, the Balrog would not have been slain.

So, not only does Pippin's idle curiosity result in Gandalf returning as Gandalf the White, it also results in the removal of the Balrog. What part might the Balrog have played in the War of the Ring? We don't know. It might have simply stayed in Moria. Or it might have come out and assaulted Lothlorien from the slopes of the mountains. Would the Galadhrim have been able to fight on two fronts? Again, we don't know. 

Even if the Balrog played no part on the War, it would still have been hanging around in Moria into the Fourth Age. Moria would thus continue to be a no-go zone. Any orcs that found their way into Moria would have been safe from Aragorn's pogrom.

text:
It should be noted that Pippin's saving of Faramir had another consequence, in the book.

Faramir, along with √âowyn and Merry, laid stricken in the Houses of Healing at Minas Tirith following the battle of Pelennor Fields, as they had been poisoned by battling the Witch King. Aragorn entered the city to heal them using athelas, which fulfilled a prophecy about the true King of Gondor. As said by the Warden of the Houses: "The hands of the king are the hands of a healer, and so shall the rightful king be known."

This immediately led to Faramir recognizing Aragorn as the rightful King, and given that he was a beloved son of Gondor (and technically the last Steward following Denethor's death) would sure have affected the rest of the population. Without this, it may not have been possible for Aragorn to have mustered the remaining forces of Gondor to attack the Black Gate of Mordor; without an army, Sauron may not have been convinced of the legitimacy of the attack and thus moved his own forces to counter, which opened the way for Frodo and Sam to reach Mount Doom.
